item.title: Improving DNS Privacy with Oblivious DoH in 1.1.1.1
item.description: Oblivious DoH (ODoH) makes secure DNS over HTTPS (DoH) queries into private queries which prevent the leakage of client IP addresses to resolvers. The new proposed ODoH standard addresses this problem and today we are enabling users to use this protocol with 1.1.1.1
item.author: (Tanya Verma)

item.title: How to configure CSP Headers for Static Website Hosted in Azure Blob Storage
item.description: This post is about configuring CSP Header for Static Website Hosted in Azure Blob Storage. If you’re running a Single Page application, hosting it from Azure Blob service it easy and cost effective. Long back I wrote a blog post on how to do this - Simple Static Websites using Azure Blob service. One of the challenge in this approach is configuring security headers. If you check your application with tools like https://securityheaders.com, you will be getting a very low score, like F.

item.title: thought leaders and chicken sexers
item.description: From the moment I started paying attention to the tech industry, Paul Graham was there. My first job out of college was in SoMa, around the corner from the Justin.tv offices, and his essays were just floating around in the ether, impossible to ignore. His popularization of Lisp was a small part of why I tried Clojure, and a big part of why Clojure was successful.

item.title: Adopting Azure serverless architectures to help reduce CO2 emissions – Part 1 | Sustainable Software
item.description: Introduction Today most workloads run on provisioned servers and the demand for compute is increasing every day. However not all workloads need dedicated compute. The idea behind this blog is to present a typical architecture of a Scalable web application with some long running operations and how we can build this architecture in a more carbon efficient way (adopting principles of https://aka.ms/sse/learn).

item.title: Modern Web Development with Blazor & .NET 5
item.description: Blazor isn't just for new apps! Blazor in .NET 5 is integrated seamlessly with ASP.NET Core to enable modern full stack web development with .NET. In this session we'll show you how you can use Blazor and ASP.NET Core together to add rich client-side interactivity to both new and existing apps. You'll learn how to use Blazor components from your existing MVC views and Razor Pages, handle server-side prerendering, setup authentication & authorization, improve load time performance, and then deploy your app into production.

item.title: March 8, 2020 - Minimal March - Blazor Buttons and Commands !coffee
item.description:
Fritz works on more of the BlazorWebFormsComponents project and answers your questions about Blazor
Questions 15:16 - I found often that when trying to run more enterprise kind of software, often windows is left out instead of linux. 16:53 - Windows is banned in my office, so I have to get my .NET in somehow. 18:25 - And IT doesn't want to maintain another OS. We're just Ubuntu or OSX. 23:12 - No one ever really clarifies whats what secure about it, it's normally just the statement "it's not secure". 23:49 - I wouldn't rule out learning from you, just because of what you use or who you work for. 24:23 - What do you do at Microsoft? 59:58 - Are there decorators or something for this kind of boilerplate in C#? 1:00:30 - Is BlazorWebFormsComponents a Razor Component Library. I would like to use it in my projects if it has controls that I could use? 1:01:21 - I have been using neovim on st terminal with omnisharp. Vim is extremely fast and snappy. Almost better than vs code but way too far to get close to actual VS. 1:10:17 - What is the flavor of Linux to which MS most contributes to? 1:47:32 - Can you install nuget packages from vim? 1:52:38 - Why do you need attribute [Parameter]? I've never used Blazor. 1:53:45 - Child content, is that a child safety feature? 2:14:52 - Are Blazor calculations faster than Javascript code?
Source at: https://github.com/FritzAndFriends/BlazorWebFormsComponents
item.author: (Jeffrey T. Fritz)

Why does CreateWindowEx take the extended style parameter as its first parameter instead of its last? | The Old New Thing
item.description: Windows 3.0 expanded the Create­Window function by adding a new extended style parameter, resulting in the Create­Window­Ex function. You would expect that the new parameter would go at the end of the parameter list, but that’s not where it ended up.
